newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT -- Corrective dlr/yen seen capped at 117.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT -- Corrective dlr/yen seen capped at 117.

text.p: Dollar/yen could rise to 117 in the short-term, before the larger downtrend reasserts itself, analysts said.

"We're upside corrective within the larger May downturn. So 117 (yen), it looks like that's where we're heading," said Ken Boyer, foreign exchange analyst at MMS International. "Then I look for some renewed selling."
After a brush with the 117 level, which corresponds with the daily high on May 16, Boyer said a move back down to 114 yen was likely.
But analysts said they would not rule out a rise to the 117.50 to 118 yen area, where the 38.2 percent retracement target (117.90) from the decline to 111.98 yen from 127.47 can be found.

"For now it still needs to work off some oversold daily RSI studies," said John Moore, foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data. "Daily slow stochastics, they're in buy mode. So that seems to suggest dollar/yen could correct a little bit more."
Below 114 yen, the next support is placed at 113.52. The 109.30 region marks an important long-term retracement target, if Tuesday's low at 111.98 is taken out, analysts said.
Meanwhile, dollar/mark is rangebound, with a firm short-term bias, in the congested zone between 1.6850 and 1.71, analysts said.
"Today we're within yesterday's range and there is just not a whole lot of momentum there," said Boyer.
"I think it's the same sort of deal (as dollar/yen), some daily studies are suggesting it can score some gains," Moore added.
At 1130 EDT/1530 GMT on Friday, dollar/mark was at 1.6906/11, off from 1.6924/27 at the open. Dollar/yen was at 115.51/56, off from 115.68/73.
